importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico in Handlova, Slovakia, marking a pivotal political and social event in the country.
The date of the final verdict by the Slovak Specialized Criminal Court, closing a high-profile trial on terrorism charges against Juraj Cintula.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the assassination attempt occurred, highlighting a moment of national crisis and political instability.
The duration of the trial, from July 2024 to October 2025, showing the legal and societal response to the attack over a year-long process.

keyTakeAways: A Slovak court convicted Juraj Cintula of terrorism for shooting Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.
Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker, writer, and public activist, admitted to shooting Fico five times from a distance of over one meter.
Fico was seriously injured, with wounds to his abdomen, hip, hand, and foot, and has since returned to public duties despite ongoing health issues.
The court ruled that Cintula targeted a political leader specifically, supporting a terrorism charge over lesser charges of murder or attack.
Cintula claimed he wanted to stop Fico’s policies, which he said damaged Slovak freedom and culture, and described the attack as a 'scream against fear that is paralyzing the society'.
The verdict reflects deep societal divisions between populist Fico and liberal, pro-EU opposition parties.
Fico has accused the opposition of undermining democratic standards, while opposition leaders claim Fico has eroded media freedom and covered up corruption.
The defense argued that not all attacks on officials constitute terrorism, but the court found that targeting a prime minister was intentional and politically motivated.
Cintula stated he would appeal the verdict, calling it 'unjust', and the case remains a symbol of political polarization in Slovakia.
Fico has publicly forgiven Cintula, signaling a personal reconciliation despite the serious nature of the attack.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Slovak court has sentenced 72-year-old Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024, with the attack occurring in Handlova and being judged as terrorism due to its targeted nature against a political leader. Cintula, a former mine worker and public activist, admitted to shooting Fico five times and claimed he opposed Fico’s policies on Ukraine, media, and culture, describing the act as a 'scream against fear'. The verdict reflects deep political polarization in Slovakia, with Fico blaming the opposition for societal anger, while opposition parties accuse him of undermining democracy. Despite the severity of the attack, Fico has forgiven Cintula, and the case remains a symbol of the country’s ongoing political and social tensions.
title: Slovakia court sentences suspect in attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico to 21 years
